title: How You Can Protect Your Skin This Summer

content: Summertime means plenty of fun in the sun! But sometimes, you can put your skin at risk. Here are some tips you can use to protect yourself.
Protect Your Skin From UV Rays

Ultraviolet (UV) rays result in damaging effects on the skin (sunburns, accelerated skin aging) as well as increase your risk of developing skin cancer – the most common cancer in the United States. It is estimated that 1 in 5 Americans will develop skin cancer in their lifetime.
Protecting yourself against UV exposure is the most preventable risk factor for all skin cancers.
Apply Broad-Spectrum Sunscreen With an SPF of 30 or Higher
Broad-spectrum sunscreen protects against both UVA and UVB rays, both emitted from the sun.
As far as how much to apply, a good rule is two finger lengths worth of sunscreen for your face and neck.

For your body, 1 ounce (2 tablespoons) or one shot glass worth is recommended. Apply 30 minutes before UV exposure, and when staying outdoors, reapply every 2 hours. If you are sweating/and or exposed to water, sunscreen should be reapplied every 90 minutes instead of every 2 hours.

content: Make sure to apply sunscreen even on cloudy summer days.
Don’t forget to apply sunscreen to your ears – that’s often a commonly missed area that gets a significant amount of UV exposure.
Invest in Sun-Protective Clothing (UPF Clothing)

A common misconception is that if you are wearing clothing, you are protected. However, the ability of a fabric to block UV rays is based on a variety of factors and is measured using ultraviolet protection factor (UPF). UPF indicates how much of the sun’s rays are absorbed by the fabric before it reaches your skin. A typical white cotton T-shirt has a UPF of 5 to 7. But clothing with UPF labels offer optimal protection at a UPF of 50. Nowadays, there are an increasing number of fashionable options for athletic, leisure, and travel UPF clothing.
Sun-Protective Behavior

UV rays are strongest from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. If you can avoid being outside during this time, you can reduce your risk of UV exposure. Opt for a wide-brimmed hat of 2-3 inches to protect your ears, head, and neck rather than a baseball cap. Remember, if you can, look for shade.

sections.heading: Unclog Your Pores
content: Hot summers not only increase the risk of UV-related skin concerns, but higher summer temperatures can also exacerbate chronic skin conditions such as acne and eczema. For acne-prone skin, summer can mean increased skin congestion and breakouts. Using cleansers with chemical exfoliants such as salicylic acid can help unclog pores after sweating and exercise.

Avoid scrubbing the skin or using mechanical exfoliants (such as harsh beads), which can disrupt the skin’s barrier and irritate the skin. It’s also important to moisturize with non-comedogenic moisturizers that are free of oils and shea butter.
Rinse Off Chlorine

Most swimming pools contain chlorine to kill bacteria. Frequent and prolonged exposure to chlorine in swimming pools can be drying for the skin, and for those with eczema, this can be a recipe for an eczema flare-up. To restore hydration with increased pool use during the summer, rinse off with a cool shower immediately after getting out of the pool.

Using a mild hydrating cleanser will help restore your skin’s pH balance, but if you don’t have access to a cleanser, rinsing off with water will do. After rinsing off, apply a moisturizer to hydrate your skin barrier. And if you still plan to stay outside, reapplying broad-spectrum sunscreen is a must.
